What a fucking emotional roller coaster the ending was. Really well written script, although I feel that "normal" people would never behave like that with a stranger hobo. There are accounts of teens behaving like that towards bullied teens while under the influence of alcohol, but that's in a setting where they have trained themselves over time to disregard the bullied kid as a "human" which allows their psyche to treat him/her that way.

With a stranger, even a hobo, their psyche wouldn't be at that level.

She was actually hallucinating and the proof of that lies with her saying "I'm glad" at the start of her trip and repeating it out loud at the end. In her delirious state she's talking out loud saying that she was "glad" that she had hana as she's imagining what the future could be like if things would've worked out, when in reality she's coming to the end of her high and is still bloody and bruised laying dying in the bathroom. The last panel is proof of that, read it again and pay attention to her strained dialogue (TLDR There is no salvation, author is ruthless).

If it was a trip, it was way too vivid and distinct to be a trip. The look on her face in those last few panels is basically one of "I can't believe how bad it got". Her previous trip was established to basically be her blissfully blanking out, but not really a concrete scenario (which is pretty accurate if you've ever talked to a heroin addict). You wouldn't be thinking of your problems, but rather they'd just wash away.

Upon further research on Shindol's twitter, there's a tankoubon coming out for this series that will include new content, and if any of the teasers he's posted have anything to say about this, there might actually be hope for Saki-chan after all.

＠metroid I'm not trying to fight with you here, and if you all you're looking to do is insult people over trivial things then whatever. But the outcome is only going to be "obvious and [definitive]," to me at least, is if Shindol himself says it is explicitly the case or can be quoted saying it somewhere already. Even then, with the whole Death of the Author theory/viewpoint, even if Shindol, the author, says that's the case I don't even have to accept it as truth since an interpretation separated from his intention is just as valid if the world of literary analysis and criticisms has anything to say about it.
Anyways, I'm not looking to change your mind or argue with you about this, you've made up your mind, as have I, on this; arguing with you anyways is just going to result in tautologies on both sides.

@reveiller There is no room  for interpretation when the outcome is OBVIOUS and DEFINITE.  Now you can go back to your bed and tell yourself any nice lies that help you to sleep.  Seriously anyone who thought this would end in a nice  and happy way either doesn't know Shindol at all or lives in Wonderland.

For all the folks that were curious like me and needed something like this to really get some personal closure/guidance on what interpretation to take, I took the liberty of taking to reddit to see if someone could provide a professional medical opinion on Saki's condition at the end of this: https://www.reddit.com/r/NoStupidQuestions/comments/4k37zt/could_a_child_be_born_and_survive_under_these/

With this info, I can comfortably assume that she was able to survive, or at the very least has the POSSIBILITY of survive, which is far better than nothing. And she fucking deserves it. She deserves it so much.

I think it was a dream, the last moment of happiness the drugs provided her just before death. That being said, it's obviously an ending meant to the reader's interpretation, and that is mine. You can believe what you will, it's OK.  By the way,  the glasses should have come from when she was rummaging through whatever she might still have left on with her in front  of the mirror,  we're not shown that she was rummaging but the onomatopoeia for rummaging,  ゴソ　ゴゴ,  is present there, but anyway it shouldn't be something to overthink over lol, it wouldn't be weird for her to have clung onto a memento of her previous life all along (or maybe she just never happened to discard them and always had them with her)  and at the end of her road, burnedned by all her mistakes, it wouldn't be unnatural for her to want to remember her previous life, thus producing and wearing the glasses (for the last time?
